lines.text: Enter LEONATO, with DOGBERRY and VERGES

lines.speaker: leonato
lines.text: What would you with me, honest neighbour

lines.speaker: dogberry
lines.text: Marry, sir, I would have some confidence with you that decerns you nearly.

lines.speaker: leonato
lines.text: Brief, I pray you for you see it is a busy time with me.

lines.speaker: dogberry
lines.text: Marry, this it is, sir.

lines.speaker: verges
lines.text: Yes, in truth it is, sir.

lines.speaker: leonato
lines.text: What is it, my good friends

lines.speaker: dogberry
lines.text: Goodman Verges, sir, speaks a little off the matter: an old man, sir, and his wits are not so blunt as, God help, I would desire they were but, in faith, honest as the skin between his brows.

lines.speaker: verges
lines.text: Yes, I thank God I am as honest as any man living that is an old man and no honester than I.

lines.speaker: dogberry
lines.text: Comparisons are odorous: palabras, neighbour Verges.

lines.speaker: leonato
lines.text: Neighbours, you are tedious.

lines.speaker: dogberry
lines.text: It pleases your worship to say so, but we are the poor dukes officers but truly, for mine own part, if I were as tedious as a king, I could find it in my heart to bestow it all of your worship.

lines.speaker: leonato
lines.text: All thy tediousness on me, ah

lines.speaker: dogberry
lines.text: Yea, an twere a thousand pound more than tis for I hear as good exclamation on your worship as of any man in the city and though I be but a poor man, I am glad to hear it.

lines.speaker: verges
lines.text: And so am I.

lines.speaker: leonato
lines.text: I would fain know what you have to say.

lines.speaker: verges
lines.text: Marry, sir, our watch tonight, excepting your worships presence, ha taen a couple of as arrant knaves as any in Messina.

lines.speaker: dogberry
lines.text: A good old man, sir he will be talking: as they say, when the age is in, the wit is out: God help us! it is a world to see. Well said, i faith, neighbour Verges: well, Gods a good man an two men ride of a horse, one must ride behind. An honest soul, i faith, sir by my troth he is, as ever broke bread but God is to be worshipped all men are not alike alas, good neighbour!

lines.speaker: leonato
lines.text: Indeed, neighbour, he comes too short of you.

lines.speaker: dogberry
lines.text: Gifts that God gives.

lines.speaker: leonato
lines.text: I must leave you.

lines.speaker: dogberry
lines.text: One word, sir: our watch, sir, have indeed comprehended two aspicious persons, and we would have them this morning examined before your worship.

lines.speaker: leonato
lines.text: Take their examination yourself and bring it me: I am now in great haste, as it may appear unto you.

lines.speaker: dogberry
lines.text: It shall be suffigance.

lines.speaker: leonato
lines.text: Drink some wine ere you go: fare you well.
Enter a Messenger

lines.speaker: messenger
lines.text: My lord, they stay for you to give your daughter to her husband.

lines.speaker: leonato
lines.text: Ill wait upon them: I am ready.
Exeunt LEONATO and Messenger

lines.speaker: dogberry
lines.text: Go, good partner, go, get you to Francis Seacole bid him bring his pen and inkhorn to the gaol: we are now to examination these men.

lines.speaker: verges
lines.text: And we must do it wisely.

lines.speaker: dogberry
lines.text: We will spare for no wit, I warrant you heres that shall drive some of them to a noncome: only get the learned writer to set down our excommunication and meet me at the gaol.
Exeunt
